title: I have just finished reading all of Taleb’s books and Thinking, Fast and Slow. What should I read next if I enjoyed all of these? - Quora
tags: Antifragile: Things That Gain from Disorder (2012 book)

response.answer_text: I enjoy both Taleb and Kahneman. The common denominator I see is two brilliant iconoclasts who pioneered their own fields. I don’t think either one is always right, their value is they always have a defensible opinion—not conventional wisdom—that is usually unexpected and always sheds light on an issue even if they’re wrong. If that is what appeals to you about those books, here are some others with similar qualities. I don’t say these people are always right, but they think for themselves and always come up with a useful insight that isn’t likely to occur to others: The Logic Of Failure: Recognizing And Avoiding Error In Complex Situations (9780201479485): Dietrich Dorner: Books Amazon.com: The Emergence of Probability: A Philosophical Study of Early Ideas about Probability, Induction and Statistical Inference (Cambridge Series on Statistical And Probabilistic Mathematics) (9780521685573): Ian Hacking: Books The Uses of History for Decision-Makers: Richard E. Neustadt, Ernest R. May: 9780029227916: Amazon.com: Books To Engineer Is Human: The Role of Failure in Successful Design The Managerial Revolution: What is Happening in the World (9780837156781): James Burnham: Books The Politics of Large Numbers: A History of Statistical Reasoning The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions: Dr. Dan Ariely: 9780061353246: Amazon.com: Books
